subject: Re: [junit] Is it possible to mix junit4 tests with legacy junit3 	tests
msgSnippet: As a general case, AFAIK most of the documentations says that you have to choose one or the other. In the code, a different runner is responsible for each kind
messageBody:
As a general case, AFAIK most of the documentations says that you have to
choose one or the other. In the code, a different runner is responsible for
each kind of test case. To see any annotated tests at all you'd need the 4.x
runner, while to see any testXxx tests, you'd need the 3.x runner. Which, I
believe, means no mixing.

Just to be clear, you're using a JUnit3.x style test suite with a JUnit3.x
test case to which you want to add a single JUnit 4.x test? Where I need to
extend TestCase (or something that extends it, which by default will run the
class using the JUnit3.x runner) and still want some of the features of
JUnit4, I annotate the test case class with the @RunsWith(JUnit4.class) or
Suite.class or some other dedicated JUnit4 runner.

Phill

On 6/16/09, cwwojcik <cwwojcik@...> wrote:
>
> Hi All -
>
> I am finally moving to junit4 and would like to keep my old tests (in
> junit3) while adding new tests using junit4 annotations. Here is an example
> of my old tests:
>
> package com.test.libraries;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import org.apache.log4j.*;
>
>
> public class AllTests {
>
> public static final Logger _logger = Logger.getLogger(AllTests.class);
>
> public static Test suite() {
> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite("Test for com.clinworx.libraries");
> _logger.debug("Beginning unit testing for com.clinworx.libraries");
> //add JUnit Tests below suite.addTestSuite(Class.class);
> suite.addTestSuite(StandardLibrariesTest.class);
> _logger.debug("Ending unit testing for com.clinworx.libraries");
> return suite;
> }
> }
>
>
>
> package com.test.libraries;
>
> import junit.framework.*;
> import org.apache.log4j.*;
>
>
> public class StandardLibrariesTest extends TestCase {
>
> public static final Logger _logger =
> Logger.getLogger(StandardLibrariesTest.class);
>
> public StandardLibrariesTest (String name) {
> super(name);
> }
>
> public void testNumberOne() {
> assertTrue(true);
> }
> }
>
> Is it possible to add the following to StandardLibrariesTest.java and have
> it run?
>
> @Test
> public void numberTwo() {
> assertTrue(true);
> }
>
> Thanks for the help.
>
> Carter
